items.title: 'dict' object has no attribute 'pk' - when trying to GroupBy and Count
items.body:
Hello,

I am trying to do a group-by and count in one of the API calls. However, it is failing constantly with tastypie. The query produces the correct results, I tried the following:
```
def get_object_list(self, request):
        res = super(CovidResource, self).get_object_list(request)
                 .values('location_name', 'latitude', 'longitude')
                 .annotate(total_incidents=Count('possibly_covid'))
        print(res)
        return res
```

Even though the `print(res)` contains the proper results, `return res` is failing, producing the following trace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tastypie/resources.py", line 227, in wrapper
    response = callback(request, *args, **kwargs)

    return self.get_resource_uri(bundle)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tastypie/resources.py", line 836, in get_resource_uri
    return self._build_reverse_url(url_name, kwargs=self.resource_uri_kwargs(bundle_or_obj))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tastypie/resources.py", line 815, in resource_uri_kwargs
```

This is my model
```
class CovidIncident(models.Model):
    location_name = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    latitude = models.FloatField()
    longitude = models.FloatField()

    # common-covid

    #sometimes-covid-sometimes-flu

```

And this is my resource:
```
class CovidResource(ModelResource):
    class Meta:
        API_LIMIT_PER_PAGE = 0
        queryset = CovidIncident.objects.values('location_name', 'latitude', 'longitude').annotate(total_incidents=Count('possibly_covid'))

        max_limit = 0

        allowed_methods = ['get', 'post']
        authentication = ApiKeyAuthentication()
```

items.title: Supported Django versions clarification
items.body:
Hi @georgedorn and others,

The master branch's README.rst currently indicates support for:

"Django - 1.11 (LTS), 2.0 (LTS) or 2.1".

Given that Django v2.0 is not a Long Term Support (LTS) release, I think the "(LTS)" should be removed from after "2.0".

Also, given that the Django 2.2 pull request has been merged into master: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/pull/1588, will the master branch's README.rst be updated to say that Django 2.2 (LTS) is supported?

items.title: Strange "pk" field with PUT and with always_return_data
items.body:
This simple procedure shows a strange "pk" field appearing only when updating (PUT) a resource:

Create:
```
$ curl -H 'Content-type: application/json' -X POST -d '{"field1":"value"}' http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/model1/
{"field1": "value", "id": 1, "resource_uri": "/api/v1/model1/1/"}
```

Update (PUT):
```
$ curl -H 'Content-type: application/json' -X PUT -d '{"field1":"value"}' http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/model1/1/
{"field1": "value", "id": 1, "pk": "1", "resource_uri": "/api/v1/model1/1/"}
```

Update (PATCH):
```
$ curl -H 'Content-type: application/json' -X PATCH -d '{"field1":"value"}' http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/v1/model1/1/
{"field1": "value", "id": 1, "resource_uri": "/api/v1/model1/1/"}
```

This causes unexpected behavior on my client, as it sees an unexpected field.

items.title: How to flow authorization methods through child/nested resources
items.body:
Asked this question on SO: 
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49762928/using-authorization-methods-on-a-nested-resource

Pasting it here for visibility:
Is it possible for tastypie to understand that I want it to use the same authorization methods for filtering out objects from a nested Resource?

```
class ProjectResource(ModelResource):
    def authorized_read_list(self, object_list, bundle):
        object_list.filter(user=bundle.request.user) # return projects only the user created

class ProjectGroupResource(ModelResource):
    projects = ToManyField(
        ProjectResource,
        attribute='projects',
        null=True,
        blank=True
    )
```
The authorized_read_list method doesn't fire when accessing the ProjectGroupResource, so I get all projects, including non-user created ones. I was under the assumption that since I'm passing a ProjectResource ref, it would attempt to simulate a get_object_list, which should trigger authorized_read_list with the bundle.

items.title: `get_multiple` shuld peform a single query to the database.
items.body:
Currently, the method `get_multiple` makes a single query per-object. A single query is possible. 

There is currently a PR in this direction that was never merged: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/pull/701 From this PR I don't like that new methods are added and cache as well is added. We could use the `obj_get_list` method first and then decided if we want to use its cached version.

Best, 
Jorge.


To make Travis happy and to make the code better this needs to be dealt with.

items.title: TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
items.body:
I'm hitting what appears to be a logic error in the `dehydrate` method of `ToManyField` class in _fields.py_:
The code in question starts at line 856: 
```
        if the_m2ms is None:
            if not self.null:
                raise ApiFieldError("The model '%r' has an empty attribute '%s' and doesn't allow a null value." % (previous_obj, attr))

        if isinstance(the_m2ms, models.Manager):
            the_m2ms = the_m2ms.all()

        m2m_dehydrated = [
            self.dehydrate_related(
                Bundle(obj=m2m, request=bundle.request),
                self.get_related_resource(m2m),
                for_list=for_list
            )
            for m2m in the_m2ms
        ]
```
Let's say `the_m2ms` is `None` and `self.null` is `False`. The code will not raise an error, will not execute the `if isinstance` clause and will land on the `for` iteration. At this point a `TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable` is thrown.

To replicate this, create a `ModelResource` subclass  with a self-referencing related field:
```class MyResource(ModelResource):
    children = fields.ToManyField('self', 'children', null=True, full=True)
```

items.title: Django 2.0 support
items.body:
Django 2.0 is currently in beta.

```
tastypie/resources.py:2036: AttributeError
        if getattr(self._meta, 'queryset', None) is not None:
            # Get the possible query terms from the current QuerySet.
>           query_terms = self._meta.queryset.query.query_terms
E           AttributeError: 'Query' object has no attribute 'query_terms'
```

It seems like internal attribute ``query_terms`` will be removed.
In order to have a smooth transition for the users once it is released, this should be resolved.

items.title: Django 1.9 not fully supported
items.body:
related: #1395

django-tastypie states in the README that Django 1.9 is supported, but request.REQUEST is used somewhere in current master: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/blob/ea010ffb09f2a30db4acfb734b4315242652da29/tastypie/authentication.py#L528

The removal of WSGIRequest.REQUEST is stated at the Django 1.9 release notes:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/releases/1.9/

items.title: Security Issue
items.body:
Hello Django-tastypie security,

I sent an email a week ago to the security email address: tastypie-security@googlegroups.com but I have not heard a response, so I am posting my email here.

My name is Peter Robinson and I am a product security expert at Intel working in Longmont, Colorado.

I cloned your latest git repository at: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie

I ran your latest version of Django-tastypie, version 0.13.3  through our Static Code Analyzer  (SCA) tool.

I wanted to report to you the findings of our SCA tool. The SCA tool that we are using is called Checkmarx

Please see my “Conclusions” remarks after each potential issue listed below.

I am interested in hearing your thoughts about each of the potential vulnerability issues.

Thanks for your time ,

Peter


Checkmarx found 2 High Vulnerabilities and 1 Low Vulnerability.

Because of the nature of a static code analysis tools in general, false positives may be found.


Scan Results Details

1 - Reflected XSS All Clients

 
![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20309295/23366555/5b8339de-fcc4-11e6-99be-e6f036ccf6e5.png)


Conclusion:  In the api function: top_level, lines 158 to 166 could potentially be used to have a defined javascript function run resulting in
cross site scripting (Reflected). This is highly unlikely.

From the https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-request-get-and-request-GET-get-in-django:

request.GET is a dictionary-like object containing all GET request parameters. This is specific to Django.
The method get() returns a value for the given key if key is in the dictionary. If key is not available then returns default value None. Read more here.
request.GET.get() is combination of above two using which key/values of a GET request can be accessed. This would be mostly used in Django Views.



2 – Second order SQL Injection

 
![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20309295/23366559/5f1f8fc0-fcc4-11e6-87fe-17d68af71f01.png)


Conclusion:  This is most likely not a valid  security vulnerability because this is the prescribed method of writing custom Django admin commands from Django.
see: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/howto/custom-management-commands/
In this case, the command would be run with: python manage.py backfill_api_keys
A user cannot “easily”  influence the result from the python list “User = get_user_model()”to cause SQL injection.
However, this would depend on how the ApiKey is used and whether or not a user can replace his own ApiKey with an arbitrary value.


3 – Information Exposure through an Error Message
![3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20309295/23366562/629b2132-fcc4-11e6-8080-8abc546209c3.png)

 
Conclusion:  This appears to be a valid error handling condition. Checkmarx is concerned that too much information is revealed to a user.
This is a Low vulnerability issue.

items.title: API Updates instead of Creates if there is a single object in the database
items.body:
I have a create endpoint for a certain object. If there is a single object already in the database, when I attempt to create another one with the API, it instead updates the single existing one.

I believe this is due to the code in lines 2091-2094 in resources.py. The logic goes that if there are not existing objects in the database it raises a DoesNotExist error. If there is more than one object in the database it raises as MultipleObjectsReturned error. But if there is a single object in the database, the single item in the database is returned.

![tastypie_create_objects_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/408926/22163178/99f26194-df06-11e6-9a2e-40e8e59c6ef5.png)

This returns the object to the function put_detail (line 1407), which assumes that this is an update function on that single item instead of a create function.

Instead, I would expect it to check against the existence of a PK or ID on the bundle. Perhaps by using the detail_uri_name or something like that.

items.title: N+1 queries in dehydrate of m2m
items.body:
Hi,

Awesome blowsome project :). Thanks for giving this much up for community.

But as every journey for everyone is not as smooth, so ...

We have a tastypie resource that depends on some other resource through m2m relationship.

Now we are doing some work in `save_m2m`, something like below

```
def save_m2m(self, bundle):
     super(ourResource, self).save_m2m(bundle)
     //some work
     return bundle
```

and after  that, before sending any data to client, it goes into dehydrate of m2m resource and under that, it have code something like 

```
self.m2m_resources = []
    m2m_dehydrated = []

    # convert the_m2ms to a QuerySet if it isn't already
    if type(the_m2ms) != QuerySet:
        the_m2ms = the_m2ms.all()

    # expects a QuerySet unlike super dehydrate method
    for m2m in the_m2ms:
        m2m_resource = self.get_related_resource(m2m)
        m2m_bundle = Bundle(obj=m2m, request=bundle.request)
        self.m2m_resources.append(m2m_resource)
        m2m_dehydrated.append(self.dehydrate_related(m2m_bundle, m2m_resource, for_list=for_list))
```

Now in it the last line `self.dehydrate_related` is causing n+1 queries since it executes each time the loop runs.

Also btw, we have already done `prefetch_related` on our querySet in Meta class. for related resource
Something like 

```
class Meta:
    detail_allowed_methods = ['patch']  
    list_allowed_methods = ['get', 'post']
    queryset = table.objects.using('default').select_related('table2') \
        .prefetch_related(
            Prefetch('table3',
                     queryset=table3.objects.select_related('table4', 'cols')
                     .prefetch_related('options', 'options__options')
                     .only(*FIELDS_TO_QUERY_API)
                     ),
            Prefetch('table4',
                     queryset=Item.objects.select_related('table5')
                     .only(*FIELDS_TO_QUERY_API)
                     ),
            'tableX',
            'tableX__options'
    )\
        .only(*FIELDS_TO_QUERY_PM_API)

    fields = (... our fields ...)
    serializer = UJsonSerializer()
    validation = ModelFormValidation(form_class=resourceForm)
    always_return_data = True
    ordering = ['started_at']
    filtering = {
        'status': ('in',)
    }
    cache = OnlyCacheHeaders()
```

And  currently n+1 queries happening when we do `post-list` in tastypie.

I am not sure how to debug and find root cause of issue.

items.title: "y-m-dTh:m:s" isn't parseable anymore
items.body:
Hey guys,

This commit 8cc07f64 looks to improve the performance of how datetime fields are parsed but it introduced a new issue, example: {{2010-11-10T03:07:43}} isn't parseable anymore:

```
In [1]: from django.utils import datetime_safe
In [2]: value = "2010-11-10T03:07:43"
In [3]: from tastypie.utils import make_aware
In [4]: year, month, day = value[:10].split('-')
In [5]: hour, minute, second = value[10:18].split(':')
In [6]: make_aware(datetime_safe.datetime(int(year), int(month), int(day), int(hour), int(minute), int(second)))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-6-3f6b5d00106f> in <module>()
----> 1 make_aware(datetime_safe.datetime(int(year), int(month), int(day), int(hour), int(minute), int(second)))
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'T03'
```

The docsting says that the code should handle this case while it's not the case actually https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/blob/master/tastypie/fields.py#L384

Why there is no unit test covering this case ?

Cheers!

items.title: Option to avoid computing total count
items.body:
Right now, the `Paginator` class computes a `total_count` of all objects to return as part of the `"meta"` portion of the api response.  In most casees, I think that seems pretty reasonable.  However, for very large databases (I have a use case in mind with tens or hundreds of millions of rows), the act of simply computing an accurate count can be very slow.  This is already acknowledged in the docs, where there is a very thoughtfully written implementation of a reasonable "approximate count" solution with Postgres in mind (not sure how well it works for other backends).

With that in mind, would it make sense to add a configurable option to avoid computing totals in the `"meta"` section of the api response?  I.e. if you chose `compute_totals=False` then the API simply wouldn't compute totals at all.  But the default could be `compute_totals=True`.

items.title: How to setup cache to be private?

```
 def cache_control(self):

        'max_age': 36,
        'must-revalidate' :True,
        'private': True,
        'public': False

```

The code which processes this is cache_control_overload which states:

```
This function patches the Cache-Control header by adding all
keyword arguments to it. The transformation is as follows:

* All keyword parameter names are turned to lowercase, and underscores
  are converted to hyphens.
* If the value of a parameter is True (exactly True, not just a

* All other parameters are added with their value, after applying

```

items.title: In Python 3, ApiKey list in admin is not useful
items.body: The ApiKey list in the admin isn't useful under Python 3 because ApiKey only implements **unicode**. Other models in `tastypie.models` use the `@python_2_unicode_compatible` decorator, but for some reason ApiKey does not. I'll prepare and submit the 2-line fix.

"If self.attribute is a composite attribute (country__president), then we get exception here, because our class doesn't have the attribute country__president, but have the attribute country, which have the attribute president). And it's taking into account in self._attrs:

```
self._attrs = attribute.split('__') if attribute is not None and isinstance(attribute, six.string_types) else []
```

Maybe I should open issue + test on this case?"

items.title: __repr__ should return str in Py2
items.body:
Hi all! Thanks for maintaining project!

`__repr__` in bundle should return str function in Py2. It's standard python-behavior. And some programs may rely on that fact.
https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__repr__

Also, I have problem in one Django-project with representation of bundles. My bundle.data can contain dictionary with models. Models have defined `__unicode__`. But Django under the hood convert `__unicode__`-result to ascii in `__repr__` and `__str__` functions. And calling `__repr__` inside dictionary while representing bundle caused `UnicodeDecodeError`.

Example:

```
bundle.data = [
    {
        'model': my_model  # repr(my_model) will return str, not unicode
    }
]

repr(bundle) # calling __repr__ for my_model, it's Python's behavior
             # UnicodeDecodeError
```

Thanks!

items.title: `obj_update` will take one more database search when bundle.obj.pk is an int value
items.body:
These code lines make `obj_update` function always raise NotFound when bundle.obj is not None:

```
    bundle_detail_data = self.get_bundle_detail_data(bundle) if bundle.obj else None
    arg_detail_data = kwargs.get(self._meta.detail_uri_name, None)

    if not bundle_detail_data or (arg_detail_data and bundle_detail_data != arg_detail_data):
    ....
```

The reason is `get_bundle_detail_data(bundle)` always return an int num and `kwargs.get(self._meta.detail_uri_name, None)` always return a str num, their returns must not be equal.

items.title: Need a much safer default: `DjangoAuthorization` should not allow `read` access to all model object
items.body:
Looking at `tastypie/authorization.py` (around like 133 -- master branch on 1/4/2016), the default, both `read_list` and `read_details` bypass `user.has_perm()` check, which is quite unsafe and is a bad default.

Django's Admin default is unconventional. So, I could see how it was misinterpreted.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/es/1.9/topics/auth/default/#permissions-and-authorization

```
The Django admin site uses permissions as follows:
*   ... 
* Access to view the change list, view the “change” form and change an object is limited to users with the “change” permission for that type of object.
```

Essentially, "change_xyz" is the permission code for both "read" and "update". I think the better default would be following Django's Admin:

``` python
diff --git a/tastypie/authorization.py b/tastypie/authorization.py
index 1d6f5aa..44b2d56 100644
--- a/tastypie/authorization.py
+++ b/tastypie/authorization.py
@@ -151,22 +151,14 @@ class DjangoAuthorization(Authorization):
         return model_klass

     def read_list(self, object_list, bundle):
-        klass = self.base_checks(bundle.request, object_list.model)
-
-        if klass is False:
-            return []
+        # By default, follows `ModelAdmin` "convention" to use `app.change_model`
+        # `django.contrib.auth.models.Permission` for both viewing and updating.
+        # https://docs.djangoproject.com/es/1.9/topics/auth/default/#permissions-and-authorization

-        # GET-style methods are always allowed.
-        return object_list
+        return self.update_list(object_list, bundle)

     def read_detail(self, object_list, bundle):
-        klass = self.base_checks(bundle.request, bundle.obj.__class__)
-
-        if klass is False:
-            raise Unauthorized("You are not allowed to access that resource.")
-
-        # GET-style methods are always allowed.
-        return True
+        return self.update_detail(object_list, bundle)

```

items.title: Error with default value for UUIDField primary key
items.body:
I'm getting an error with primary keys having a default value.
Let's consider a model with an `UUIDField` (new in django 1.8)
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/ref/models/fields/#uuidfield

``` python
import uuid
from django.db import models
class MyModel(models.Model)
    id = models.UUIDField(primary_key=True, default=uuid.uuid4)
```

Docs suggest to set a `default=uuid.uuid4` to automatically generate a value for the field on object creation.
When we try to perform an update (i.e. PUT), a new empty instance of `MyModel` is created in `tastypie.resources.Resource.build_bundle` and, having the field a `default`, it is assigned a new `id`.
Therefore the update fails, since the newly created instance has a different `id` from the one of the object to update.

items.title: Duplication issue with query using filter on M2M relation in Meta class for Resource.
items.body:
Hi all, I've encountered an odd issue that results in the output from a GET call containing duplicate objects due to the manner in which the Django query is constructed and yields rows.

For off, I'm using Django 1.7.9 with Tastypie 0.12.1. Database is Posgresql 9.4

The setup required to duplicate this issue is a little involved.

First off, the models:

```
class A(models.Model):
    pass

class B(models.Model):
    instances_of_a = models.ManyToManyField(A, related_name='instances_of_b', null=True, blank=True)
```

now for the problematic Resource definition:

```
class AResource(ModelResource):
    class Meta:
        queryset = A.objects.all()

class BResource(ModelResource):
    instances_of_a = fields.ManyToManyField(AResource, 'instances_of_a', full=True, null=True)

    class Meta:
        queryset = B.objects.filter(instances_of_a__isnull=False)
```

When a GET is performed against BResource, any instances of B that are associated with more than one A object via the instances_of_a M2M relation will be returned multiple times in the response from BResource. The number of times an instance of B will be returned is equal to the number of A objects associated with it by the instances_of_a M2M relation.

The reason for this is due to the SQL Django generates to produce the Queryset. The SQL in question looks like this

```
SELECT
"database_schema_name"."id"
FROM "B"
 INNER JOIN "A"
   ON ("B"."id" =
       "B_A_Assn"."B_id")
WHERE ("B_A_Assn"."A_id" IS NOT NULL);
```

The result of this SQL is the issue describe above wherein there will be duplicate items in the queryset.

Probably the simplest solution to this is to not use a related filter in the fashion described but I would image it would be possible to detect for this kind of condition and handle it?

items.title: Resource.deserialize() ignores format parameter
items.body:
Hi there,

I just found that Resources's deserialize() methods ignores the "format" parameter.
It instead tries to get the format from the requests's content-type (falling back to application/json).

```
 def deserialize(self, request, data, format='application/json'):
        """
        Given a request, data and a format, deserializes the given data.
        It relies on the request properly sending a ``CONTENT_TYPE`` header,
        falling back to ``application/json`` if not provided.
        Mostly a hook, this uses the ``Serializer`` from ``Resource._meta``.
        """
        deserialized = self._meta.serializer.deserialize(data, format=request.META.get('CONTENT_TYPE', 'application/json'))
        return deserialized
```

I would've sent in a pull req but I'm not sure which way to go - change 

```
format=request.META.get('CONTENT_TYPE', 'application/json')
```

to

```
format=request.META.get('CONTENT_TYPE', format)
```

or  drop the parameter from the method?

Cheers,
Patrick

items.title: Debugging Clarity - 'ModelDeclarativeMetaclass' has no attribute 'Meta' when passing type rather than instance
items.body:
I ran into a bit of a confusing error message today. I added a few model resources to API, and suddenly everything broke for a few of the endpoints. 

I got the following error message

```
AttributeError at /crm/work-orders/15/
type object 'ModelDeclarativeMetaclass' has no attribute 'Meta'
```

It turns out that this was a really simple issue. I had forgot to instantiate model resources I was registering.

 Changing from:

``` python
version_1_api = Api(api_name='v1')
version_1_api.register(WorkOrderResource)
```

to:

``` python
version_1_api = Api(api_name='v1')
version_1_api.register(WorkOrderResource())
```

fixed the issue for me. However, this solution was not obvious, and there was no real clear indication that this was the issue, short of reading the source.

I know this goes against what the documentation states, but it was a simple mistake in a large file, which took a bit of time to figure out.

Can an exception be added, when registering an endpoint, that checks to see if it is an instance or a type, and clearly notify the user of what the issue is?

items.title: Per-Request Alterations To the Queryset doesn't work as described
items.body:
As per this Django ticket: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/11629 the functionality described by Tastypie here: http://django-tastypie.readthedocs.org/en/latest/cookbook.html#per-request-alterations-to-the-queryset doesn't work.

In particular, although the code runs fine right now (Django 1.7, Django 1.8), the time being used isn't what's implied by the documentation (it's the time when the queryset was created, not when the request occurred). Also, it seems in Django 1.9, this code will actually fail: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/internals/deprecation/#deprecation-removed-in-1-9
(search "Passing callable arguments to querysets will no longer be possible").

items.title: RemovedInDjango19Warning: django.utils.importlib
items.body:
So I downloaded the latest version of tastypie by running `pip install -e git+https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie#egg=TastyPie`. But opening a url got me an `ImportError` with message `cannot import name resources`.
So to dig a little bit, I launched the shell with `python manage.py shell` and tried to import resources like so: `import from tastypie resources`. And then I got this:

``` shell
RemovedInDjango19Warning: django.utils.importlib will be removed in Django 1.9.
  from django.utils import datetime_safe, importlib
```

What is error due to? I am using Django 1.8 on Python 2.7.  
Anyway to get tastypie to work on Django 1.8?

items.title: Related objects are not updated - Django 1.8
items.body:
Django 1.8 disabled the assignment of unsaved foreign key values to models. This causes setattr in full_hydrate to raise a ValueError which results in the model being added to bundle.related_objects_to_save.

In save_related the FK is loaded from bundle.obj attributes since the FK is always there for our model. This causes the further logic to always use the old value of our Related object.

see: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/ref/models/fields/#django.db.models.ForeignKey.allow_unsaved_instance_assignment

items.title: Best practices in avoiding circular imports?
items.body:
My problem is that it's hard to avoid circular imports when using GenericForeignKeyField and structuring code logically.

Is there any method like Django's "get_model" but for resources? A solution would be of course not having "/api/v1/org/1/statuses/" method for the status updates.

More or less pseudo-code example (some imports etc removed):

api/org/resource.py

``` python

from api.models import Organization, StatusUpdate
from api.user.resource import UserResource
from api.statusupdate.resource import StatusUpdateResource

from .authorization import OrganizationAuthorization
from .authentication import OrganizationAuthentication

class OrganizationResource(ModelResource):
    members = fields.ToManyField(
        UserResource,
        'members',
        full=True, null=True, blank=True)
    creator = fields.ForeignKey(UserResource, 'creator', full=True)

    class Meta:
        queryset = Organization.objects.filter(disabled=False)
        resource_name = 'organization'
        always_return_data = True
        authorization = OrganizationAuthorization()
        authentication = OrganizationAuthentication()

    def prepend_urls(self):
        return [
            url(r"^(?P<resource_name>%s)/(?P<pk>\w[\w/-]*)/statuses%s$" %
                (self._meta.resource_name, trailing_slash()), self.wrap_view('get_statuses'), name="api_get_statuses"),
        ]

    def get_statuses(self, request, **kwargs):
        """
        GET /api/v1/org/1/statuses/
        """
        try:
            # Create bundle and fetch the requested object from cache
            bundle = self.build_bundle(data={'pk': kwargs['pk']}, request=request)
            obj = self.cached_obj_get(bundle=bundle, **self.remove_api_resource_names(kwargs))
        except ObjectDoesNotExist:
            return HttpGone()
        except MultipleObjectsReturned:
            return HttpMultipleChoices("More than one resource is found at this URI.")
        res = StatusUpdateResource()
        status_update_contenttype = ContentType.objects.get(
            app_label="app",
            model="statusupdate"
        )
        queryset = StatusUpdate.objects
        queryset = queryset.filter(object_id=obj.pk, content_type=status_update_contenttype)
        queryset = queryset.order_by('-created').all()
        bundles = []

        for obj in queryset:
            bundle = res.build_bundle(obj=obj, request=request)
            bundles.append(res.full_dehydrate(bundle, for_list=True))

        return self.create_response(request, bundles)
```

api/statusupdate/resource.py

``` python
from tastypie.contrib.contenttypes.fields import GenericForeignKeyField
from tastypie.resources import ModelResource

from api.org.resource import OrganizationResource
from api.event.resource import EventResource

from api.models import StatusUpdate


class StatusUpdateResource(ModelResource):
    content_object = GenericForeignKeyField({
        Event: EventResource,
        Organization: OrganizationResource
    }, 'content_object')

    class Meta:
        resource_name = 'statusupdates'
        queryset = StatusUpdate.objects.all()
```

items.title: “use_in” / “full_detail” does not work for related field
items.body:
I got this structure :

```
class DossierResource(ModelResource):    
    proposals = fields.ToManyField(
        'api.api.ProposalResource',
        'proposal_set',
        full=True,
        full_detail=True,
        full_list=False
    )

    class Meta:
        queryset = Dossier.objects.all()
        resource_name = 'dossiers'


class ProposalResource(ModelResource):
    dossier = fields.ToOneField(DossierResource, 'dossier')

    votes = fields.ListField(
        attribute='vote_api_list',
        use_in='detail',
    )

    class Meta:
        queryset = Proposal.objects.all()
        resource_name = 'proposals'
```

When I get `api/v1/proposals/?format=json` it works, I don’t get my _votes list_ but when I get `api/v1/dossiers/?format=json` I get the entire vote list (I want to get that list only in proposal's detail view and dossier's detail view)

Does not work either if  `votes` is a `ModelResource` instead of a `ListField`

What I can do is to set two Proposal Resource :

```

class DossierResource(ModelResource):    
    proposals = fields.ToManyField(
        'api.api.ProposalDetailResource',
        'proposal_set',
        full=True,
        full_detail=True,
        full_list=False,
        use_in='detail'
    )

    proposal_list = fields.ToManyField(
        'api.api.ProposalResource',
        'proposal_set',
        full=True,
        full_detail=False,
        full_list=True,
        use_in='list'
    )

    class Meta:
        queryset = Dossier.objects.all()
        allowed_methods = ['get']
        resource_name = 'dossiers'
        filtering = {
            'title': ALL,
            'reference': ALL
        }


class ProposalResource(ModelResource):
    dossier = fields.ToOneField(DossierResource, 'dossier')

    class Meta:
        queryset = Proposal.objects.all()
        resource_name = 'proposals'


class ProposalDetailResource(ModelResource):
    dossier = fields.ToOneField(DossierResource, 'dossier')

    votes = fields.ListField(
        attribute='vote_api_list',
        use_in='detail',
    )

    class Meta:
        queryset = Proposal.objects.all()
        resource_name = 'proposals'
```

But I can’t get the two fields (proposals and proposal_list) to get the same name in the api

items.title: Patch not returning updated data for prefetched fields
items.body:
When patching a prefetched field of a resource  (configured as always_return_data), even though patch is correctly made, returned data is outdated, it returns the data from the prefetch cache.

This issue is fixed by the following PR: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/pull/1282 and is very similar to the bug fixed by the previous commit: https://github.com/django-tastypie/django-tastypie/commit/b78661d76d1e73e2d90a8a1bcfcae90fcafb50b1

items.title: Django 1.8 compatibility
items.body:
Running Django 1.8 and Django-Tastypie 0.12.1 on Windows, Python 2.7, running `manage.py check` fails with this error:

```
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tastypie\resources.py", line 2210, in Base
ModelResource
    @transaction.commit_on_success()
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'commit_on_success'
```

The decorator was removed in this version of Django, so says Django documentation

> These features have reached the end of their deprecation cycle and so have been removed in Django 1.8 (please see the deprecation timeline for more details):
> ...
> - the decorators and context managers `autocommit`, `commit_on_success`, and `commit_manually`, defined in django.db.transaction
>   ...

items.title: django-tastypie==0.12.2 & django=1.8.b2
Field doesn't appear to be a valid datetime string
items.body:
I have custom validation of some form

```
class MyForm(forms.Form):
    my_field = forms.DateField(input_formats=['%d/%m/%Y',])

class MyResource(ModelResource):
    class Meta:
        validation = CleanedDataFormValidation(form_class=MyForm)
        ...
```

I want to use validation of MyForm, but when I submit it with some errors tastypie returnes next:

```
{error:"Datetime provided to 'my_field' field doesn't appear to be a valid datetime string: 'undefined-02  2001-06'"}
```

I know that 'undefined-02  2001-06' is not valid datetime, but it does not render as valid errors list. So when I render list of my errors I can not get what field has rised an exception and can not display any message
How can I ignore this validation and use (maybe) django form validation instead?
